turns.content: What was the inspiration behind the choreography for the ballet, Giselle?

There is no one specific inspiration behind the choreography for the ballet Giselle, as it was created by a group of collaborators in the mid-19th century. The ballet was choreographed by Jean Coralli and Jules Perrot, with a score by Adolphe Adam, and it tells the story of a young peasant girl named Giselle who falls in love with a nobleman named Albrecht. However, when she discovers that Albrecht is engaged to another woman, she dies of a broken heart and becomes a ghostly figure known as a Wilis. The choreography for Giselle was influenced by a variety of dance styles, including classical ballet, folk dances, and court dances, and it is known for its romantic and ethereal quality. The ballet has since become a beloved classic of the dance repertoire, inspiring countless adaptations and interpretations over the years.

Yes, the costumes in Giselle do reflect the time period in which the story takes place. The ballet was first performed in 1841, so the costumes that were designed for the original production were based on the fashions of the mid-19th century. The peasant costumes would have been more rustic and simple, while the noble costumes would have been more elaborate and fashionable. In the second act of the ballet, the "Wilis" wear flowing white dresses or tutus, which are meant to evoke a ghostly, ethereal quality. These costumes have become iconic over the years, and are often associated with the ballet.
